thread.title: Apple iPhone 6s and 6s Plus in Australia: how and when can you get one?
thread.title_full: Apple iPhone 6s and 6s Plus in Australia: how and when can you get one? | afr.com

author: David Ramli
title: Apple iPhone 6s and 6s Plus in Australia: how and when can you get one?
text:
The iPhone 6S will get new docks for charging Share on twitter by David Ramli The Apple iPhone 6s and 6s Plus smartphones have launched and are set to hit Australian shelves from September 25.
But with the vast majority of people still buying their devices from mobile carriers like Telstra , Singtel-Optus and Vodafone Hutchison Australia, how and when will you be able to get one?
None of Australia's telcos are accepting pre-orders and all are carrying the same generic iPhone 6S digital flyer supplied by Apple.
Pre-orders will begin on September 12 at 5.01pm. This is to match up with Apple's directive to telcos to start accepting pre-orders from only 12.01am California time.
This is also when all the telcos will ramp up their marketing and advertising, using templates that have been approved by Apple HQ.
Australian telcos could theoretically have started releasing their pricing to the public from midnight on Thursday evening / Friday morning. But most are planning to wait until Saturday afternoon to prevent their rivals from tactically matching or lowering their prices to win more customers.
A key point to watch for customers buying the Apple iPhone 6S using a 12-24 month contract is how much extra you're forced to pay above the contract price to get the phone you desire. The long-term trend amongst the Big 3 carriers has been to pass on more of the cost to consumers.
The Australian dollar has fallen substantially against the US dollar since the Apple iPhone 6 launch last year and this could lead to plans being more expensive.
 But all the mobile carriers have been fighting to increase the amount of download data that comes included with phone plans and they're desperate to keep winning more customers to maintain market share and growth.
So if you can spare the time and effort, call your telco and see what kind of offer they're willing to make to keep you as a customer.
It's also worth thinking about buying the phone outright before getting a "BYO" contract with your operator of choice. Doing so will save you money and give you more control.
